Description: Fragment of wall of South Ionian pottery cup or bowl; interior: glaze fired orange-red; interiorglazed with added red ring lined in white; exterior: glazed above, reserved towards foot with single glaze line; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B1
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer identifies the sherd as coming possibly from a Type 10.1 or Type 10.2Bγ but the lack of a rim prevents further identification. Type 10 cups were mass produced and include numerous variants. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type V (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Vallet and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B1 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Numerous Type 10 South Ionian cups have been found at Naukratis, as well as in the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra and at Megara Hyblaea on Sicily, and at Berezan on the Black Sea (Posamentir 2006, 165). The place of production of Type 10 South Ionian cups is determined as probably Miletus based on the results of NAA analysis carried out by Hans Mommsen, Bonn, on another sherd (British Museum 1886,0401.1025) from Naukratis and of same shape, decoration, and fabric.
The fabric is finer and thicker than for most such cups; this may be from a bowl.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXIII, no. 345)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 672, no. 306)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 54, no. 26)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.168) (Phase 3)
